author: JuliaRegistrator

comments.body:
Hello, I am an automated registration bot. I help manage the registration process by checking your registration against a set of [AutoMerge guidelines](https://juliaregistries.github.io/RegistryCI.jl/stable/guidelines/). If all these guidelines are met, this pull request will be merged automatically, completing your registration. It is **strongly recommended** to follow the guidelines, since otherwise the pull request needs to be manually reviewed and merged by a human.

## 1. New package registration

Please make sure that you have read the [package naming guidelines](https://julialang.github.io/Pkg.jl/dev/creating-packages/#Package-naming-guidelines-1).

## 2. [AutoMerge Guidelines](https://juliaregistries.github.io/RegistryCI.jl/stable/guidelines/) are all met! ✅

Your new package registration met all of the guidelines for auto-merging and is scheduled to be merged when the mandatory waiting period (3 days) has elapsed.

## 3. To pause or stop registration

If you want to prevent this pull request from being auto-merged, simply leave a comment. If you want to post a comment without blocking auto-merging, you must include the text `[noblock]` in your comment. 

_Tip: You can edit blocking comments to add `[noblock]` in order to unblock auto-merging._

<!-- [noblock] -->
<!---
this_is_the_single_automerge_comment
--->

This package name strikes me as a little generic. Since it’s related to Manifolds.jl, maybe `ManifoldGroupTools`?

Otherwise (or probably in any case), I would ask for substantially more documentation. Right now, there is no way to tell what functionality the package provides.

Thank you for your comments!

This package has a narrow usefulness for people working with groups. It is a dependency of other packages of mine (those are of general usefulness) that I wish to publish. So:
1. If it were possible to keep this package on GitHub and have it as a dependency, I would do that, but I understand this is not possible?
2. I really don't care about the name (as this is only ever going to be used as a dependency, I guess). `ManifoldGroupTools` is as good as any other name. **Do I have to re-register with that other name?**

> This package has a narrow usefulness for people working with groups. It is a dependency of other packages of mine (those are of general usefulness) that I wish to publish.

Yes, that was exactly my impression, and that's totally fine.

> 1. If it were possible to keep this package on GitHub and have it as a dependency, I would do that, but I understand this is not possible?

Yes, a dependency of a registered package also has to be registered, which makes this absolutely fine to register.

> 2. I really don't care about the name (as this is only ever going to be used as a dependency, I guess). `ManifoldGroupTools` is as good as any other name.

From the description "Useful functions to work with groups defined in `Manifolds.jl`" I got the impression that this was going to be an internal dependency mainly for `Manifolds`. Hence the suggestion for the name `ManifoldGroupTools`. In general, `<NameOfMainDependentOrOrg>GroupTools` seems like the most appropriate name. As the maintainer of `Manifolds`, you can use that as sort of a name space that you own (just like many packages have `Base` packages).

Also, for packages that aren't user facing but merely serve as a dependency, having a long and descriptive name is a good idea. That leaves `GroupTools` still open for a more general, user-facing package related to group theory.

The longer and more descriptive the package name (and especially for "internal" packages), the less scrutiny I would put on it for registration, e.g., in terms of how much documentation there should be at the time of registration. In general, I think there should always be a paragraph in the README that explains the context and scope of the package and links to the main dependent.

It's also never a bad idea to set up a very basic online documentation with Documenter that just shows all the docstrings (or, I suppose you could rely on JuliaHub doing that for you automatically and link to their documentation from the README). That's definitely more optional for an internal package.

> Do I have to re-register with that other name?

Yes, unfortunately. See the FAQ on [What to do when asked to reconsider/update the package name?](https://github.com/JuliaRegistries/General?tab=readme-ov-file#what-to-do-when-asked-to-reconsiderupdate-the-package-name)
Thank you very much for the very clear and detailed explanation. I will choose a more appropriate name and re-register.
This PR can be closed, as it is superseded by #111048
